Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Topography, Boundary Currents and the Submesoscale
Award.AbstractNarration: This project addresses the dissipation of mesoscale, balanced flow in the ocean through the use of high resolution nesting experiments in two different numerical models (ROMS and the MIT general circulation model). The work specifically addresses the generation of sumesoscale, ageostrophic flows by mesoscale interactions with topography by explicitly resolving the relevant scales of 0.1-10 km in the horizontal. Numerical simulations will be designed to calculate the cascades of energy, enstrophy, and tracer variance and compare with theories, which will also be developed and improved within the scope of the project. The high resolution simulations will be performed in the Kuroshio region where strong topographic features and the the western boundary current dynamics will allow robust testing of the hypotheses. It is hoped that the work will lead to new understandings of the submesoscale regime, the dynamics that connect balance and unbalanced flows, and perhaps even lead to new parameterizations which can be used to represent these processes in ocean and climate models.

Improving climate change modelsNSF: Type I - Collaborative Research:  Topography, Boundary Currents and the Submesoscale     (University of California, Los Angeles)     Type I - Collaborative Research:  Topography, Boundary Currents and the Submesoscale     (Florida State University)State:  California, FloridaCongressional Districts:California District 30, Florida District 02Research Areas:Earth & EnvironmentOceanic currents flow along the side boundaries in their basins, mostoften along constant-depth contours on continental and island bottomslopes.  Measurements of chemical properties show that these currentsare typically leaky; i.e., distinctive water properties containedwithin the currents are often found within the adjacent interiorwaters in diluted concentrations.  The question is how this leakage occurs.NSF-funded researchers at the University of California at Los Angeles and 
Florida State University have found that the drag of the currents against the 
solid bottom generates strong horizontal gradients in the flow; that differential 
pressure force against the bottom induces the current to separate from the 
boundary; that after separation the current experiences an instability that 
generates turbulent fluctuations on spatial scales of tens of meters vertically 
and hundreds of meters horizontally (a.k.a. the submesoscale range); and that 
these fluctuations both disperse the material concentration anomalies and 
undergo a further "self-organization" process into long-lived submesoscale 
coherent vortices--whirling water masses that hang together as they move 
through the ocean--that disperse into the interior region. See the figure of 
Monterey Bay, CA that shows where the submesoscale instability ensues and 
the coherent vortex, central red patch, as a later-stage product of the 
turbulent fluctuations.  This sequence of events is demonstrated in 
computational simulations for both the California Undercurrent and the Gulf 
Stream.  Some observations of the coherent vortices created by this process 
confirm their existence.This project has thus provided an answer to how boundary currentwaters leak into the interior.  Ultimately, this advance could lead tomore accurate global circulation and climate models.  Such models mayreduce prediction errors in future climate forecasts.
